all about taking the brains see I CD and putting it on to kubernetes and taking advantage of everything that
kubernetes has to offer so to give you a little bit of history in early 2018 the
Kay native build and Kay native serving projects were created so Kay Natives serving it was all about an open source
kubernetes based server las' solution and in order to take care of the source to deployment piece of that Kay native
build was created that people got really excited about being able to build images on kubernetes but they really quickly
found that they wanted more they wanted to do things like run tests before they built the images and they wanted to plug these things together in more
complicated pipelines so that's where Tecton pipelines came from which was previously called Kay native pipelines
one of the big features of Tecton pipelines is portability so the goal is
that we have created an API spec that any CI CD vendor could comply with so
this means that I can write pipelines for my project and then I can use them with a variety of vendors or use them
with multiple tools we also want to add types into CI CD systems and we want our
pipelines to be decoupled so I can take a pipeline and I can run it against my own infrastructure or I can take pieces
of that pipeline and I can run them on their own and we want to support deploying to kubernetes very well but we
also want to support other completely different deployment targets as well like maybe mobile and a lot of people
are pretty excited about this so at the moment we have regular contributions from developers from Google's Google
Cloud B's pivotal IBM Red Hat and more and so if any of you are interested in
contributing we've put a lot of work into making it really easy to ramp up as a contributor so please join us now
particularly if you're interested in contributing but also if you just want to use this you might be wondering how does this all work so the key to how
Tecton pipelines works is it's implemented as kubernetes C RDS so C R d stands for custom resource
definition kubernetes out-of-the-box comes with a number of types like deployments pods and services but it
also has a model that lets you add your own types and and kubernetes itself so to do this you
create your own resource types and then you create processes called controllers
or operators which operate on those resources so what CR DS that we add for
Tecton pipelines I'll start with the most basic building block so the most basic building block is something we
call a step and what this is it's it's actually a container spec which is an existing kubernetes type so this is how
you say what image you want to run and how to run it what arguments to use environment variables all of that the
first new type we added is called a task so a task lets you put multiple steps
together those steps or containers will run in sequence on the same kubernetes
node the next new type is a pipeline a pipeline puts tasks together and you can
run them in any order you want you can run them in parallel you can run them sequentially and the pipeline will also
let you do more complicated things like you can take the output of one task and provide it as an input to another task
even though they run on different nodes so both of those pipelines and tasks are
things that you define once but you use again and again so to actually invoke these there are two new types we added
called pipeline run and task run which will actually invoke the pipeline or the task and since both of these need
runtime information about what infrastructure to use we added another type called the pipeline resource so
this is all the runtime information that you need to actually invoke your pipelines and tasks altogether there are
five new types of CR DS we have tasks and pipeline which you define once and
use again and again and then you invoke those using task runs pipeline runs and pipeline resources so if we go back to
